content: Why is docs#LinearMap.IsSymm restricted to sesquilinear forms instead of allowing arbitrary targets?

Because symmetry of sesquilinear forms is really like being Hermitian: the condition is
âˆ€ (x y : M), I ((B x) y) = (B y) x, and in general, there is no action of I on other target modules.

I guess this is an example where generalizing in one direction (bilinear to sesquilinear) prevents generalization in another (bilinear forms to general bilinear maps).

In any case, I've resorted to use B.flip = B as the condition (in #14986, which could do with some reviews...).
Michael Stoll has marked this topic as resolved.
